metadata.title: Deep Vein Thrombosis  Exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Deep veins, predominantly in the lower extremity (tibial, popliteal, femoral, or iliofemoral veins); occasionally, in vein of upper extremity (Paget-Schroetter  disease)
description: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a blood clot that results from abnormal coagulation, usually in a lower extremity. The DVT is often isolated in the tibial vein of the calf (i.e., a distal DVT), or more proximally in the popliteal, femoral, or iliofemoral veins (i.e., a proximal DVT or May-Thurner  syndrome)(1,2)
Symptoms of venous phlebitis and claudication due to acute or recent DVT include pain, swelling, heaviness, edema, and skin changes in the affected limb(1)
Physical examination of patients with suspected first-time  DVT lacks specificity and sensitivity. Clinical guidelines are available for the diagnosis according to risk of DVT(1,17)
Conservative management of acute DVT includes optimal anticoagulant therapy (i.e., assessment of coagulation factors), leg compression sleeves, and early-mobilization (versus bed rest)
After optimal anticoagulation is established, a symptom-limited  aerobic exercise(often walking) program may be permitted and therapeutic for ambulatory patients(1,18)

Chronic pain and disability in the affected lower extremity for longer than 3 months indicates the development of post-thrombotic  syndrome (PTS), which in most cases contraindicates all vigorous physical activity(19)

Venous thromboembolism (VTE) refers to embolization of the DVT, often to the lungs (i.e., pulmonary embolism [PE]). VTE is a major complication of DVT that increases morbidity and mortality. This Clinical Review does not cover VTE or PE

ICD-10 codes.I80.2: phlebitis and thrombophlebitis of other deep vessels of lower extremities; deep vein thrombosis NOS
ICD-10 codes.I80.3: phlebitis and thrombophlebitis of lower extremities, unspecified; embolism or thrombosis of lower extremity NOS
ICD-10 codes.I80.8: phlebitis and thrombophlebitis of other sites
ICD-10 codes.I80.9: phlebitis and thrombophlebitis of unspecified site
ICD-10 codes.I82.8: embolism and thrombosis of other unspecified site
ICD-10 codes.I82.9: embolism and thrombosis of unspecified vein; embolism of vein; thrombosis (vein) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: DVT is usually a unilateral condition and the involved extremity is usually a leg(most often the calf area)(1)
Pain, swelling, heaviness, and skin redness distal to the DVT
Patients with a subacute or chronic calf DVT experience increased pain when the foot is forcefully dorsiflexed (Homans’ sign)(1)
Tightness or dull ache in the area of the DVT

Patients with PTS have increased leg heaviness, swelling, pain, itching, muscle cramps, skin changes (i.e., ulceration and lipodermatosclerosis), and reduced mobility in ADLs(20) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors DVT. Instruct patient to follow physician’s orders regarding use of ECS Impaired functional mobilityPatient will be independent with functional mobility, including transfers and gaitTherapeutic exercise _ Implement a low-to- moderate intensity aerobic exercise program, as tolerated _ _ Explain to patient and caregiver that light exercise, such as walking, is a helpful treatment for DVT _Progress patient as appropriate. Educate patient on reintegrating physical activity at appropriate levelsEnsure that patient and caregiver are safe to perform transfers, bed mobility, and gait upon discharge . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures
contraindications precautions to test: The physical examination may be unremarkable in the early stages of first-time  DVT. For example, Homans’ sign is often falsely negative(1)

causes: Decreased velocity of blood flow (venous stasis), injury to blood vessels, and/or hypercoagulation (i.e., thrombophilia orprothrombotic state)(2)
Genetic factors/mutations that promote thrombophilia(2)–Factor V Leiden–Prothrombin G20210A–Mutated hemoglobin S (e.g., sickle cell disease)–Deficiencies of antithrombin III, protein C, and protein S
Acquired causative factors include trauma, surgical procedures, immobilization(2)
pathogenesis: DVT typically forms near the valves of the vein. Virchow’s triad describes conditions for the formation of the DVT: 1)hypercoagulability (increased tendency to clot), 2) endothelial cell injury (changes to the venous wall), and 3) venous stasis(decreased rate of blood flow)(2)

Potential outcomes of acute DVT–Propagation – expansion of the blood clot into larger veins(2)–Embolization –blood  clot dislodges from the venous wall, travels in the bloodstream, and becomes lodged in an organ(e.g., lungs, brain, heart)(2,18)–Dissolution (fibrinolysis) –process  by which the blood clot breaks down, restoring blood flow(2,18)–Organization and recanalization–the  integration of endothelium, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells inside the thrombus(organization) followed by the development of capillaries allowing blood flow to continue through the thrombus(recanalization). Exercise may promote organization and recanalization inside the thrombus(18)
Venous obstruction or valvular reflux that persists after DVT may lead to venous hypertension in the microcirculation andthe development of PTS(19)
risk factors ,: Congestive heart failure (CHF) or respiratory failure
Immobility due to prolonged sitting (e.g., air travel “economy class syndrome” or cross-country  bus ride)

overall contraindications precautions: Physical therapy should be put on hold and the physician contacted for instructions if the patient presents with increased pain and/or any of the other signs and symptoms of DVT listed above
Avoid therapeutic exercise until the patient has been on anticoagulant medications, usually for 24–72  hours. Consult with physician for any special instructions prior to beginning exercise program

Notify the physician or emergency department if the patient exhibits atypical anxiety, tachypnea (respiratory rate > 16), tachycardia (pulse rate > 100), fever, sweating, chest pain, hypotension, decreased percentage of oxygen saturation in blood (SpO 2), or lightheadedness (1)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: The physical examination may be unremarkable in the early stages of first-time  DVT. For example, Homans’ sign is often falsely negative(1)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document date of DVT diagnosis and probable cause (e.g., hypercoagulability, immobilization, postoperative)

course of treatment.medical management: Document any past or current treatments, such as anticoagulants, elastic compression stocking (ECS), vena cava filters, and/or earlymobilization and ambulation mechanical thrombectomy or thrombolysis intermittent compression
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury The following medications may be prescribed for DVT prophylaxis in high-risk  patients(5) Low-dose  heparin Low-molecular-weight  heparin (LMWH) Pentasaccharide Warfarin The following anticoagulants may be prescribed to treat DVT(1) LMWH Unfractionated heparin Warfarin
diagnostic tests completed: Wells Criteria algorithm may be used clinically to predict the risk of DVT(17)
High-frequency  color (contrast) Doppler venography is the gold standard diagnostic test for distal DVT. However, it is invasive and may be painful(1)
Compression ultrasonography is used when the pretest probability of DVT is moderate to high(1,6,17)
D-dimer  assay may be used alone or in conjunction with compression ultrasound (depending on pretest probability) to assist in ruling in/out a DVT(1,6)
Magnetic resonance direct thrombus imaging (MRDTI) may be used to diagnose DVT, especially in patients wearing a cast.However, it is expensive(1,6,17)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Ask patient about the use of any unprescribed medications or treatments for DVT
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Generalized pain and tenderness may be found distal to the DVT
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night due to leg discomfort
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., shortness of breath, chest pain)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Any history of shortness of breath? Is supplemental oxygen needed by the patient? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask about any past history of DVT or PE; recent trauma and/or surgery; recent prolonged bed rest; pregnancy
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, and complications of pregnancy. Caesarean delivery increases the risk for DVT
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs). Any use of oral contraceptives?
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Ask about physical activity during work or recreation
social and occupational history.living environment: Identify and document potential barriers to mobility and independence in the home, number of floors in home, whether caregivers are available if needed, etc. Are any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (while tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Assess height and weight, and determine BMI. Is weight loss indicated?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: May be given if patient has had a recent orthopedic surgery (e.g., knee replacement, hip replacement); monitoring devices (e.g., personal safety alarm) may be required if safety is questioned (e.g., due to PE)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess for impairment of static and dynamic balance (e.g., Tinetti test, Berg Balance scale)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Circulation –Diminished pulses (although the condition is venous, not arterial) may reflect edema and/or spasm –Venous palpation may promote tenderness distal to the DVTMeasure limb circumferences at site of DVT in affected limb and compare to contralateral limbAssess ability to perform functional mobility tasks safely, such as the Timed Up-and-Go  Test (TUG). Note whether pain limits mobility. Use FIM, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe for altered or antalgic gait pattern. Assess patient’s ability to walk safely over-ground  or on a slow-moving  treadmill belt. Note whether pain or muscle spasm limits safe ambulation without assistance Assess if mobility is limited by premorbid orthopedic condition
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of the uninvolved extremities and trunk with manual muscle testing (MMT). May use a functional strength test (e.g., 5 Times Sit-to-Stand  Test)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes in affected limbAssess ability to perform self-care  safely, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Scan for reduced sensation in affected limb
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosispositive when squeezing the posterior calf muscles elicits painpositive if the patient has pain in the calf when standing on toes, or pain in popliteal space on passive forceful and abrupt ankle dorsiflexion with the knee flexed. The reliability of this test is poor, having very low sensitivity and specificity, in cases of recent DVT(1)

other: Patients with DVT are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Therapeutic ultrasound should not be used in the area of DVT. No forms of electrical stimulation should be applied (locally or remotely) in patients with active DVT(21)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: DVT/reduced aerobic endurance, strength, balance, and flexibility; increased falls risk;

maintenance or prevention: Prevention and management of DVT and sequelae includes avoiding prolonged immobilization, elevating the lower extremities, use of graduated ECS, intermittent pneumatic compression, regular aerobic exercise, such as walking, ankle pumps, and anticoagulation therapy(14) A meta-analysis  of five studies (n = 3,048) found that early ambulation for the management of PE did not increase the risk of DVT progression, development of a new PE, or death compared to bed rest management(16)
Results of a Cochrane review indicated that graduated ECS may reduce the incidence of DVT in patients during the postsurgical period(15)

Authors of a 2015 systematic review found that patients with recent trauma may benefit from sequential compression devices or foot pumps in order to minimize the incidence for DVT. Foot pumps were more effective at minimizing risk for DVT than sequential compression devices(25)
patient education: Rule out  (3) Musculoskeletal –Osteoarthritis –Hematoma –Myositis –Synovitis –Osteomyelitis –Tumors –Leg trauma –Tendonitis –Baker's cyst –Fracture –Muscle strain (e.g., gastrocnemius)(8) Neurological –Sciatica –Lower-limb  paralysis Venous –Phlebitis –PTS –Compressed veins Arterial –Arteriovenous fistula –Acute arterial occlusion Generalized edema –Cardiogenic –Nephrogenic –Dysproteinemic  Cutaneous –Dermatitis –Cellulitis –Lipoedema –Panniculitis Localized edema –Pregnancy –Oral contraceptives –Limb immobilization

Other considerations In most cases of uncomplicated DVT, bed rest should not be prescribed as part of the initial treatment –Authors of a randomized clinical trial (n = 53) in Switzerland found that leg compression plus ambulation was superior to bed rest for reducing thrombus progression in patients receiving routine anticoagulation therapy for DVT(8) –Authors of a large prospective cohort study (n = 2,038) in Spain found that the risk of developing PE in the first 15 days after DVT in patients receiving anticoagulation therapy was not different between an ambulation group and a strict bed rest group(9) Specific instructions for physical therapy are needed from the referring physician for patients with an existing DVT who are not receiving anticoagulant therapy. In some cases, an inferior vena cava filter may be used that requires special consideration

Treatment summary Therapeutic exercise –Low-to-moderate  intensity therapeutic exercise may be prescribed for patients with medically managed DVT as it does not worsen symptoms or increase the risk of PTS and it tends to improve functional mobility.(7,10)However, high-intensity aerobic  exercise (> 80% of maximum) should be avoided because compared to low-intensity  (less than 60%) exercise, it is associated with increased platelet and coagulant activity that may increase the risk of thrombotic events(22) –There are specific guidelines on when patients with DVT may return to vigorous recreational physical activity.(11) Athletes with DVT may gradually return to their regular ADLs after optimal anticoagulation therapy is achieved. Progressive increases in sport-specific  training intensity can begin, provided the athlete is asymptomatic during sport-related  activity and monitored carefully for recurrence of DVT. Patients should not participate in contact and collision sports until anticoagulation therapy is completed(23) –Authors of an RCT (n = 72) in Sweden found that exercise alone or exercise with ECS did not exacerbate symptoms or increase complications in patients receiving anticoagulation therapy soon after DVT. Recanalization of thrombi did not occur any faster in the two exercise groups compared to the control group(12) –Authors of a 2008 systematic review found that walking exercise may help reduce leg symptoms in patients with DVT(18) –. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Increased risk of DVT due to inpatient statusDecreased risk of DVT Risk-reduction strategies _ Early mobility after surgery and out of bed to chair as early as possible following bed restProgress functional mobility training as toleratedEncourage activity upon discharge  Patient at risk for PTS, edema, and painReduce risk of PTS _Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ If ordered by the physician, ensure that patient wears graduated ECS during exercise(13) _ _ (Please see Treatment summary , above)Follow physician’s orders regarding discharge of ECSsEducate patient on signs and symptoms of DVT. Instruct patient to follow physician’s orders regarding use of ECS Impaired functional mobilityPatient will be independent with functional mobility, including transfers and gaitTherapeutic exercise _ Implement a low-to- moderate intensity aerobic exercise program, as tolerated _ _ Explain to patient and caregiver that light exercise, such as walking, is a helpful treatment for DVT _Progress patient as appropriate. Educate patient on reintegrating physical activity at appropriate levelsEnsure that patient and caregiver are safe to perform transfers, bed mobility, and gait upon discharge .
